posts.com:
Advice on making a successful advice post on /o/:

If you are looking to get advice on a possible car purchase or car related problem, be sure to include:

What car or cars you are looking at or as detailed a description of the problem as possible. Include make, model, year, mileage, condition, any know faults, the asking price, and what your budget is!

If people have to ask you for every detail, you aren't going to get many replies!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
1.)Get financing ahead of time/know your credit. You always want to have a financing option in hand before you go to a dealership. Nothing wrong with negotiating a better deal with them once you get there, but never go in empty handed. This way you can have idea of how much you can afford to spend, and what a car is going to cost you

2.)Do your research. Know what values KBB/NADA/Edmunds/TrueCar are listing for the cars you are interested in. Also know what other dealerships are listing similar cars for. Dealerships will prey on the uninformed, so make sure that you are

2b.)If you don't know enough about cars to inspect one yourself, arrange to get any used car inspected or bring someone who DOES know what to look for. It's surprisingly easy to polish up a turd and get it passed inexperienced eyes

3.)Never take the first offer, unless it's a place like CarMax that doesn't negotiate. Dealerships know the game, and they always get a certain number of people to bite on the first offer. make them work a little to get your business

4.)You can negotiate on more than the price. Oil changes, services plans, warranties, accessories are all fair game.

5.)In today's world, internet sales departments are your friend. You can send a blanket email to 3 or 4 dealerships and get them to compete for your business, let them haggle with each other before you ever haggle with them

6.)Get them to print you a Buyers Order for any car you are seriously, that is what you negotiate from. It will look like pic related, and itemize every line of the sale. Don't let them 4 square you or hand write shit on a piece of paper. Get a buyers order

7.)Never be afraid to walk away from a deal. If you have a bad feeling, sleep on it. There will always be other cars

They can have guns after jumping through several hoops. But aktually carrying a gun is next to impossible because that requires a completely different license which only a few hundred people out of 83 Million have.
Basically your regular sports shooter license only allows you to carry an unloaded and locked and stored away weapon to be transported between a shooting range or a gunsmith and your home.
Gun must be empty, in a locked case and the case must be out of your reach. e.g. in the trunk.

>>26294171
1) Hit local hardware store
2) Acquire round hickory tool handle about 20 inches long and 1.5 inches in diameter
3) Use a thin, round wood rasp for the four grooves around the handle
4) Use a flat wood rasp to round rown the edges at both ends
5) Drill a hole for the lanyard
6) Sand down the entire thing with #100 or so grid paper
7) Cover it in boiled linseed oil and let dry for about a week
Ta-daa, hickory bonker for no more than 10 bucks if you got the basic tools at home.
That being said: I got a Cold Steel Brooklyn Shorty in my shitbox under the passenger seat. Never had to use it but it sure feels good not to be completely unarmed even if my shithole of a country doesn't allow carrying guns.

I have a hatchet under the driver's seat of my truck. It's really there for practical /out/ purposes, anywhere I need it I'll be going in the truck anyway so it makes more sense to leave it there, but it serves a backup purpose as a melee weapon if shit goes down. I also carry a gun but if the circumstances are right I'd rather club somebody with the blunt end of the hatchet, it gives me the chance to end stuff without killing somebody, don't have to worry about hitting a bystander, way less chance of legal trouble, and I'd much rather lose an $80 hatchet to an evidence locker than an $800+ gun. The "what the fuck" factor of a dude getting out with a fucking axe might help de-escalate some situations too. posts.name: Anonymous

>>26304311
I bought it as a while ago and the previous owner was an absolute troglodyte who had no idea what bike maintenance is. They get a few problems to my knowledge. The early models had a problem with the front sprocket coming loose because it was just held on by a standard nut without any locking mechanism on it but 97/98 the changed that. They are known to eat the standard voltage regulator but you can get a new one online for around 50 coins. The water pump shits itself from reports too but it is just a case of slapping a new impeller on it, around 90 coins. Because the oil is stored in the frame the head bearings can overheat and go notchy too but that is about it. Of is had been well maintained these are all things that should have been addressed. Easy to work on, fun, reliable bikes. They can do mega miles

>>26305290
Yep it showed up on monday nearly 2 full calendar years after placing the order and over a year after their Q3 2021 target date. They've been busting ass to get orders out now that the bikes have been let out of the port. My opinions so far are that it's a good start for them. I admire that even though they had to reverse course on a few things (like the quick release battery) they delivered most of what was promised. The biggest issue is the ergonomics. The seat unironically feels like it's made out of wood, the suspension is rock hard and not adjustable. I hear some weird intermittent noises when riding, but nothing that concerns me. The brakes are unimpressive especially the rear which might as well not even be there. It's great for urban and suburban riding and I took it out on my favorite twisty road to get that picture and it was pretty nimble out there as well. There's no place for thigh grip though obviously.

posts.com: can any br/o/s that work flat rate here tell me what it's like? I'm a lubber at a dealership that is about to move up a rung on the ladder, and am curious about the various strategies that you guys may use for work flow management or any tips you have.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26306129
flat rate isn't necessarily good. Typically if you're used to quick service shit getting you 10 book hours in ~8 hours of work, flat rate is gonna basically cut your pay hardcore.
Quit and go find another job.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26306137
I know that the more prolonged jobs that require a daig, for example maybe electrical, can be net negative. How would you balance something like that? People at the dealer here typically do like to maintain their cars, so we do alot of upsell work too.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26306155
yea basically if you take longer than what the book says you lose money. That basically means any hangup that prevents you from finishing the work means its a paycut.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26306155
>How would you balance something like that?
Find another job that doesn't pay flat rate.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26306129
Assuming you work at Volvo, get really good at replacing SPA evaporators if you aren't already. Also, just try and sell everything you can. Coolant looks a bit discolored? Sell a flush. 120k miles and no recent signs of spark plugs? Sell spark plugs. Take an extra 2 minutes before each service and test drive the car before you pull it in the shop. If it doesn't drive straight and you sell an alignment, there's another 1.5 hours for about 15 minutes of work

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26307111
Turbo shaft seal might be letting go, letting oil get into the charge pipe. Or you've got a lot of positive pressure in the crankcase and it's driving excess oil into the intake via the PCV.

Either way, clean it all up with a rag, take off the intake piping and clean around the seal between the metal piping and the plastic where it's leaking. Put it back together and snug up the hose clamps reasonably tight. Then monitor over the next week or two. If it's pushing a lot of oil out, enough to make it look nearly as bad as it is now, you might have a problem to sort out. Ingesting oil isn't fantastic for an engine, it could potentially make it knock or detonate.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
For a while, I've had a book that lists every single Italian auto manufacturer. There's a brief section on OPES (Officine di Precisione E Stampaggio), the first new manufacturer in post-war Italy. Their only car, the Ninfea, was a FWD sedan that came with a 702cc or 784cc 3 cylinder engine. After a prototype was made in Turin in 1946, it was showcased at an auto show there in 1948. They obtained 100 orders, but financial issues caused the company to fold before they could fulfill any of them.

The only images online of it seem to come from a single brochure. Of the handful of examples made, I don't think any are extant.

>>26275735
No. It wasn't even a real serial production - it was an initiative research project by some engineers and designers of Central Scientific Research Automobile and Automotive Engines Institute (NAMI for short). Six cars that they made remained in their personal posession. All of them had air cooled V4 at the rear from different ZAZ models.
There was a noticeable movement of self-made automobiles in USSR, with conventions and articles in tech journals like "Technics for the youth". One of the most prominent of the constructors and his son are hosting YT channels "Combat Crew" and "Combat Crew Live" which has detailed videos about their projects (most famous one, Laura, is on the pic), maybe you will be able to understand something with YT subtitles. Also, one of the most popular youtubers found one of the soviet self-made cars on sale, fixed it and made an interview with the old man who made it:
https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLiCpP_44QZBz9D1Cp8f2Qp1auev7EKqpi

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Toyota Century Limousine made from 1989-1996 (almost all made before 92, only a few hundred made). The ultimate expression of the Japanese bubble economy excesses in a highly conservative and understated package.

A Toyota factory limo based on extending the rear doors and adding a mid segment to the VG40 Century. They came with an ice maker/drink cooler or heater and a glass set with decanter, TV that could receive terrestrial broadcasts with a VHS player, 12 disc CD changer, rear tape recorder that could also play tapes over the stereo system, glass divider with motorized curtain, rear window motorized curtain, drink cooler in the rear AC vent box, a remote that controlled the entire entertainment system and the HVAC for the rear passengers, all seats heated and massaging/ reclining rear seats as well as an interphone and options for a mobile phone for the driver and rear passengers and fax machine.

Car also featured a 4L all aluminum hemispherical pushrod V8 engine, rear air leveling, electronically adjusted shock valving and even automatically dimming headlights with a garage/dawn/dusk mode (parking lights only).

>>26301282
A lot of idiots think that technology can always get more powerful or better like it's a research tree in a videogame or something. Technologies have hard limits as to how efficient or how powerful they can be. Steam power has a defined limit to how efficient it can be based on the physical properties of water and the inevitability of energy loss through heat transfer. Same thing with chargeable batteries. We've basically reached the limit for what lithium-ion batteries can accomplish based in the physical limitations of the medium.

To get better batteries we have to explore new mediums, such as graphene or even radioisotope thermoelectric generators like on satellites and space probes.

It depends on the battery type and charging cycles.
Lipo as used in the current gen is known to have a limited lifespan, this lifespan also decreases depending on the usage pattern.
e.g. trickle charging at home usually keeping the battery below 80% and above 20% would be vastly preferable for life-expectancy.
EVs are basically huge RC-cars technically, and everyone playing with those a bit knows how to kill and deteriorate a Lipo with charging, discharging or by sticking a nail through it setting it on fire. Keeping the battery in working condition indefinitely is not an option, this is not a disputed topic.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>26306178
Oh, and I forgot to add current battery tech is not capable of providing mobility at ICE-level, this is not due to range but due to the amount of cars you can build with the available raw materials, the lithium reserves of the world are roughly sufficient to replace all cars with very bad EVs with terrible range.. it's only enough for replacing every 7th with a decent one (Tesla standard battery size).
This however rules out any other device using the same battery technology and exhausting all known resources.
We run into a similar problem with a possible hydrogen economy. (platinum and iridium).
So a different tech has to become available for EVs to make sense for general mobility.
From an EV driver's perspective this is actually rather interesting as a battery change with better technology could result in a drastic range increase... but it also means that at the moment a move to EVs means "no car for (you)!" for most of the population.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: My understanding is that "synthetic" is more of a marketing term than an actual technical definition. Most "full synthetic" oils on the shelf are not actually synthesized from scratch, but are made my breaking down larger petroleum molecules. So whether it says "full" or "semi" doesn't really matter from a performance perspective, it's more of an artificial upsell from the marketing department. Semi-synth by all accounts works just fine. To quote Blackstone Lab's FAQ page: "In our experience, oil is oil."

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
If you change it on time oil is oil

If you forget and go 30k miles it suddenly matters.

The base oil used for conventional generally has a low viscosity index (becomes much thinner with heat/thicker with cold) and needs a large amount of VI modifiers (long chain polymers) that shear much easier than the normal oil molecules. Your fancier synthetics, such as "gas to liquid" start out with a much closer viscosity to the end requirement and because of that use less polymer and will retain their viscosity index over a longer time.

Then you add in modern high compression/DI requirements for high temp high shear situations and minimizing intake sludge since DI engines don't clean themselves and you end up really having to give a shit about your oil.

TL/DR: old shitbox you change every 3k? You could probably make do with vegetable oil, fuck it. New shitbox or you suck at maintenance? Stick with the OEM recommended+synthetic

https://www.stle.org/files/TLTArchives/2021/03_March/Lubrication_Fundamentals.aspx

"By definition, the synthetic PAOs (Group IV) and heavily processed hydrocarbon oils in Group III have a VI above 120. Group II oils have a VI between 80 and 120. However, the lower the oil’s viscosity, the more the VI scale underestimates the true VI. In actuality, the viscosity-temperature behavior of some of the low-viscosity oils is better than their high-viscosity counterparts, but the way the VI calculation is performed, it ranks them lower."

I also checked the SDS for Honda 10w30 it's a group II oil. Amsoil doesn't want to say if they use PAOs, it's a trade secret according to their SDS.

posts.name: fujiwarastickershop.jp
posts.com:
>>26274024
I'll reiterate a couple of points and add on a few things from the last time I talked about it, a large reason we didn't want to work on it is because of the aforementioned but there's a large list of things that piled on top of one another and we just don't feel like doing it anymore.

- We're spending money on production that could be used for that sticker on other products instead. Pre-orders are gone, and we don't want to create a 6 week lead time (pre-order + production).

- I worked briefly with desuprint who informed me of issues with production, a large one being that Taiyo works in Inkscape primarily and the design would have to be completely rebuilt in Illustrator along with the white ink layer. desuprint also had the foil we wanted to do it on, however he has told me a while ago he is unable to reproduce it. The cost in paying him to print the stickers would be exploiting and underpaying him, or it would end up charging the customer out the ass. Paying over $10 for a sticker is stupid, and that's ironic because my store will only offer tracked shipping in the future and I apologize for any international orders because shipping is literally going to eat people's asses.

- Many things have been on my backlog for a while. In the past 6 months, nearly every original Taiyo design has been under renovation along with new(er) projects. I reflected over my FOTM drop and figured it wasn't something I wanted to force myself to do like I did before after Grandmasterslices gave me input that made me realize I was pushing myself way too hard and getting frustrated over nothing.

tl;dr no thanks, see you when the store is open someday.

>EV also use roads. Therefore EV need to be taxed.
EVs are taxed. They pay higher registration fees which translates into more per mile than gas cars pay. EV fast charging is also taxed, with fees substantially more than the gas tax per gallon equivalent.

>That is not consumer petrol
It is. You may not like the facts but that's the reality.

The only reason that electric cars have caught on is they don't need subsidies for their operating costs. Meanwhile biodiesel, ethanol, synthetic fuels, or hydrogen haven't caught on because all of those alternatives for running internal combustion engines can't compete against heavily subsidized fossil fuels without major subsidies of their own, and none of them have the kind of nation wide lobbying power that fossil fuels have to make that happen.
Nobody is going to pay $.21 a mile to drive on hydrogen when gasoline is $.10 a mile. But if electric cars are still $.04 a mile even with all the extra fees they pay then its no question why people are switching.
Simple economics. The invisible hand of the market favors electric cars because they're cheaper to run.

posts.com: 0-60 times are so pointless. literally any car ever made can turn a corner with more lateral acceleration than any sub 100k car can accelerate in a straight line. It also can last as long as you want, and doesn't require you to go at illegal speeds.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
another thing about forward acceleration: your perception of it is highly inaccurate. probably, because you actually "feel" some derivative of acceleration, not acceleration itself which is just the feeling of muscle tension. Saying a car is better because it has a lower 0-60 time is like saying a wine is better because it has a higher ABV.
Case and point: when you are on a commercial flight taking off, it feels like it's accelerating fast but it's actually accelerating as slow as a bus. It only feels that way because of how different thrust vs traction works, and creates larger higher order derivatives of speed than 99% of wheeled vehicles ever will

posts.com: My car (2011 Nissan Altima sedan CVT) hums when I drive between 40 - 60 mph. Tire treads are fine, rotated and aligned. Switching into neutral at 45 mph still has the humming sound. I hear it coming from the front of the car and I'm thinking it is on the right side. Is there any way to verify this is the source of the noise? Should I take it to the dealership? Will they just replace whatever they think is the cause without doing any troubleshooting?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26306064
Try jacking up the car and spinning the wheels by hand. Bad bearings usually make a really gnarly growling noise when spun at any speed with no load on them, like a deep "rrrrrrnnnn." There's really no need to take it to a mechanic for this job, bearings are pretty simple shit. Just don't let the brake lines leak out and you'll be fine.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Is it more pronounced while turning? Try a tight turn.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26306064
Dude, I am literally having the same exact problem. Rotated my tires to make sure, but I am almost certain I've got a shit bearing. Godspeed.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26306085
Not sure for Nissans but for most makes you need a bearing press (~$200).

Also, it seems to be just that universal time when most anons mysteriously need new bearings. I just replaced my 2 fronts. I know 3 others who need new right now. Just get it over with; probably cost you $450 at a dealership, or 3 hours of your time wrenching. After you replace you'll enjoy the smooth ride.

posts.name: Anonymous

Most company driver hate is memes, with some truth mixed in. In general, if you take pride in your work and learn the unspoken rules (like don't take your 30 in the fuel lane, and say no to flip flops) you will be ahead of 80% of the company drivers most are upset about.

Get your first year in, and immediately go find a company that pays better and doesn't hire students. You will almost always find your pay doubles.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26306827
How do most company positions feel about taking a girl along for extended period of time? I’m not talking about like, every once in a while, I mean more like 80 to 90% of my over the road time with girlfriend in passenger.

Should I just be doing local or dedicated (which I’m certain are very few with my experience and age) ?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26306869
Not him, but am familiar with the industry... Most companies allow a passenger to be brought along, but you should get their OK first though, for insurance purposes.

What sort of work you do is up to what you like. Some guys like highway, some guys like local. Highway is a good place to start though for the experience. I lasted about two years highway before the novelty wore off, and have only done various local work since then. I value home time more than I value an easy cruise down the highway. But I never regretted that time spent on the highway... I went to places that I would've never seen before, and got paid for it. Met some interesting characters along the way also.

>>26306957
They're pretty much extinct in the rust belt. If they exist in your area and you can still get parts for them they're pretty decent trucks depending on who owned them before. The 4.3 TBI is just a 350 minus the back two cylinders so it's solid and still has some balls despite being only 160hp. The 4.3 whoretec has a lot more power but has the leaky ass spider injector which is a pain in the dick. 10ish years ago a new quality replacement was around $500 so I hate to think what they're going for now.

In todays market you could probably find one of these in good condition for cheap and rebuild the engine, tranny and suspension for half of what you're going to pay for a comparable Tacoma or Ranger.

Possibly, the biggest problem with the Reliant was the engine being in the front as well, which made it nose heavy and more prone to rollover than other single front wheel 3 wheelers which had smaller lighter engines midship or in the back. As an example, the Allard Clipper was a rear engined 350cc 3 wheeler with a single front wheel and it's not as much of a meme regarding rollovers as the Robin. The Daihatsu Bee was another, 800cc, also rear engined.

>>26304518
everything everyone else said, but two more things:

1. Cops love to put speed traps at the bottom of hills so you can't see them before it's too late. Always slow down before you crest hills on the interstate, or at least be prepared to slam on the brakes

2. If you don't see a cop until it's too late and you pass him while doing way over the speed limit, DO NOT HIT YOUR BRAKES IF YOU CAN AVOID IT. If you have a handbrake, gently pull on that to slow down. Cops often look for incriminating brakelights to aim their guns at because it's easier than gunning every car that drives by. Also, if they do ticket you, if your brake lights never come on and by the time they catch up to you you're doing the speed limit, the dashcam footage will often be enough to get a judge to throw out your ticket.

posts.name: Beppu Von Braun
posts.com:
>>26301242
Amazon isn’t bad, they actually have good sales on Gearwrench a lot, and there’s this brand SATA that is basically Amazon’s brand of stuff made by Gearwrench.

If you’re just going for a basic socket set besides Gearwrench and affordable wrenches, Husky, Craftsman, and Kobalt at the local stores are straight and easy returns if you break something being a retard. And Tekton is another decent company you can find on Amazon, I think Tractor Supply Co or one of those farmer chains sells them too. Sunex as well.

If you want to go a little nicer for wrenches and sockets and get a lifetime set, SK Tools is super nice US stuff, Proto, and Williams is basically Snap On (but only for US Made, a lot of Williams is Taiwan made just like Blue Point, the budget Snap On), and then Wright Tools is another US company. Amazon carries a lot of that and they’re “Industrial” brands, which means tool truck quality without the retarded mark up.

For more specialty /o/ tools, there’s a million Chinese brands for one time use stuff, but I have yet to come across a Chink off brand pressure or vacuum gauge that is really reliable. But there are some solid mid range brands besides Gearwrench, OTC is a good one, Astro Pneumatic has some neat stuff, I know there’s a couple I’m missing.

Yes.

Good screwdrivers have some black magic voodoo, like non-magnetic quality drivers will hold screws like they have a magnet because they fit so well.

Good screwdrivers aren’t that expensive, they’re a common tool and make life a lot easier when you’re not stripping stuff out nearly as often. Pic related gives you a good show of it, the left is from a cheap generic kit, those red and black handle 100pc kits you find. The middle one is USA made Craftsman. The right is Wiha.

posts.name: Beppu Von Braun
posts.com:
>>26304626
>>26304652
Torx shows the difference the best, but you can really feel the phillips and slotted too.

Here’s a bunch of phillips but I don’t have a good real cheap generic brand for comparison.

Left to right is Husky diamond tip, Vessel ball, Vessel wood, Felo VDE, Wiha, Klein USA, an old Stanley PH1 I found, and then the right is 2 gens of USA Craftsman.

I would definitely get more Felo in the future as well, they’re quite affordable on Amazon because the meme tax of the other German brands hasn’t hit them.

Home Depot sells the Klein USA drivers, and I think they’re one of the best you can find in store since the Wiha will probably disappear once those Xmas shippers are gone, but I’m not a fan of the handle on them.

Still no final opinion on the Vessel drivers. They have a meme cult following because they’re Japanese, and they actually do fit the JIS + screws on my Jappo import Yamaha scooter better than the US and Yuro brands. Their balldriver handle is pretty comfy but the ones I got are made in Thailand while the wood composite heavy duty drivers are Japan made, so I’m sure some JDM fanbois will be salty to see Thailand on there. All I can say is I first grabbed the +1 and +2 balldrivers for like $8-$9ea before the wood set, and I would recommend that for other people if you come across a lot of Japanese cars and bikes.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26286545
Bull bars typically mount to/under the bumper and then wrap upwards without any additional support which causes any force applied to the top where you expect it to provide protection (like hitting a deer) to multiply the energy on the mounts (like using a breaker bar on stubborn bolts) and the entire bull bar folds in.
That's why we talk shit about them being a force multiplier- they wind up causing more damage then they prevent.

A bull bar can be modified to provide legitimate protection but that is much more of an involved installation.

posts.com:
I'm trying to chase lean and fuel trim codes on my 2005 sportage, 2.7 v6.
Bank 1 long term sits around 14.8% and bank 2 sits around 14.1, dousing the running engine in brake cleaner doesn't really provoke a change in either short term bank trim. Downstream o2 sensors occasionally spike above 1v.
Should the next step be new downstream sensors or getting a gauge for fuel pressure?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26289879
Put it in park, set the parking brake, then release the foot brake. The car shouldn't move at all. You could also set the parking brake, put it into park, and then release the foot brake. The order doesn't matter as long as you don't release the foot brake before you set the parking brake.
If you put it in park and release the foot brake and then set the parking brake the car will roll a little bit when you release the foot brake as the parking pawl settles in to a slot which can really wedge it in there if you're on a hill and make it tough to shift back into gear when you want to leave.

posts.com:
>>26292184
it's doubtful both o2 sensors are going bad at the same time. i would carefully check for vacuum leaks (buy or borrow a smoke machine if you can), clean your maf sensor, and run some strong fuel injector cleaner. possibly take your fuel injectors out and clean/test their spray pattern. since both banks are bad, that would make me lean toward the maf or a vacuum leak. i wouldn't just start replacing parts until you narrow down the actual problem.

>>26296249
Generally an alternator should survive being blasted with a water hose. If you live in an area with a lot of salt then chances are parts of it can corrode internally. Is the alternator not charging at all? You should try to stick a multimeter to the battery poles with the car running and check the voltage. If it's less than 14V you probably have a bad alternator. As long as the power and ground are connected to it it should produce power. I don't know about the electrical system design on your 09 Jetta but on my 94 Audi the power regulator is also a known failure point.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26296378
the battery recharges while running, but it drains while the car is off. I have the new (used) alternator in hand ready to install

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26296468
Doesn't sound like an alternator problem to me then - if that was the case the battery would also die on you while the car is running.

Generally if you have battery drain then I recommend you start checking what might be drawing battery. Sometimes you'll find there are certain modules locking themselves in ON position and powering things while the car is off. Try pulling fuses and stick a multimeter into the ports - stick the pins into the fuse holes and make sure you get good contact. Any reading which is near 0 or 0 is good. If your battery dies once a week or so, assuming it holds 60Ah you could have a fairly high draw. If you see values above 0.2A you might have your answer there.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26296511
Actually - I've done some reading on alternator diodes now and it seems like in some cases a faulty diode can discharge your battery and lead to a parasitic draw. I guess the best way of checking that is by disconnecting the main power line to the alternator and checking to see if there is amperage when the car is off to the alternator between the line and the alternator itself. If not then go back to previous plan of pulling and checking fuses.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26298558
First jump the computer to blink out the codes, that might be an important clue. If that doesn't yield anything, put on a fuel pressure gauge and see if your pressure is ok. Also check your spark plugs, plug wires, cap and rotor for obvious problems (cracks, tracks, carbon buildup etc). Make sure your air filter isn't clogged/replace if due. Check for excessive carbon buildup in the throttle body.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26298558
you say its a fuel related issue so i'll assume that it is.

generally speed isnt as interesting, but look at rpm. if it struggles with supplying fuel at higher rpm, and this applies to every cylinder (ruling out individual injectors) id instantly suspect fuel pump. youd want to check fuel pressure.

i dont think your car has O2 sensors, but they fuck up fuel trim sometimes if theyre broken. these also tend to trip trouble codes if theyre broken.

the last thing i can imagine then would be the ECM itself, but then youd probably have trouble code, also ECM failure is uncommon unless its been shorted or soaked.

i'm a hobby mechanic but the only toyota ive worked on is my mom's Yaris. i could try to give you some advice though, and i believe the first step you'll need to take is to just do general tests. check cylinder compression and fuel pressure. if cylinder compression is good then you definitely have a salvageable project. chances are you might have a bad rotor, coil, maybe injectors. you could try the old trick with spraying starter fluid into the engine through the air intake - if that helps you most likely have a fuel issue. otherwise id look into spark - coil, spark wires, spark plugs, rotor and distributor. generally if its a spark related issue you can fix it fairly cheap.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26304668
leaking fuel injector is a pretty common cause of long crank. to test (non gdi) put a fuel pressure gauge, start and run the car, then shut it off and watch for fuel pressure dropping rapidly after the fuel pump stops running. if it drops rapidly it has to be leaking somewhere, like into your engine.
if gdi you do the same thing but you have to use a scan tool to monitor the psi and not a gauge

GX: More common than the LX and uh, it's the same truck toyota's been making for a while what more is there to say?
RC F, haven't had a chance to drive one yet, we have one on display in yellow. Didn't even know about a track pack until the marketing disguised as training was assigned to me.

While I'm at it, UX is an oddity I kind of like. As an appliance it's completely adequate I only see AWD hybrids. Their sport mode fake engine noise is so bad it's comical, it's like it knows there are better cars this brand has produced and it isn't it but it can play it over the speakers!
CTs are fuel efficient and are terrible cars as cars, it's like a lexus made a prius C.
Hybrid variants of models are a grab bag of sleepy to boring to 500H torque.

Toyota's infotainment (I worked for a toyota dealer before this) overall has been the same thing steadily getting better for like 2 decades, in where the last model year they finally got a really functional version of the software. Only to then make toyota connect in the following model year. I'm glad it serves as the portal to get android auto more directly and comes on in a reasonable amount of time.

I've given up on owning any new performance cars. Dealers marking them up and ensuring the average person can't afford them, and they are in many ways worse than 20+ year old shitboxes unless you spend well over $40,000 on something. The new Integra and Civic Type R are great examples of this. I could spend $53,000 Canadian plus markup for a new Civic or buy a really clean 90s K-swapped honda product for 1/5th of the price. The older car weighs much less, is easier to fix, is just as fast or faster and has real VTEC, unlike modern Honda products.


I can't see anyone aside from wrenchlets or wealthy people buying new performance cars, and considering the next generation of performance cars are all going to be EVs or hybrid products I'd go and buy the older car you've always dreamed of because the future is bleak.

>>26305329
Do you have power going into the relay? If not you've got a broken wire between it and the switch. If you do have power at the relay (and it's good) but no power at the plug then you have a broken wire between the light and the relay. If you want to rig it you could just run a new wire after the relay into the bulb connector.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Pennzoil NISMO GT-R invasion at 2001 NISMO FESTIVAL!

2001 was a rad year! It was a rare and unique opportunity to see all the Pennzoil-sponsored NISMO GT500 cars together. And let me tells you: the legendary american oil brand stopped to sponsor one of two NISMO official team chassis in 2000 JGTC season, but returned to 2001 for sponsor the ex-LOCTITE ZEXEL GT-R car, becoming the ‘Pennzoil ZEXEL GT-R’ that year. Different from the 1998 R33, and 1999 R34 Pennzoil GT500 champions, and even helping NISMO to win the 2001 season on team standings along with the sister chassis, the Pennzoil ZEXEL GT-R has been updated to ‘Castrol PITWORK GT-R’ for 2002, losing the yellow livery and the Pennzoil sponsor once again. So yes, it means that the Pennzoil ZEXEL GT-R is no longer around us.

Another curious fact, , is that the Pennzoil NISMO GT-R BCNR33 and BNR34 pictured here aren’t “original” cars, but replica based on other chassis. Respectively, they are the 1998 ZEXEL SKYLINE and 1999 CALSONIC SKYLINE repainted as Pennzoil-sponsored cars for NISMO’s heritage.

The original Pennzoil BCNR33 has the low-downforce kit and Nicos GT banner and sometimes can be seen appearing in some events, including the NISMO FESTIVAL itself. The original Pennzoil BNR34 however, has been lost. It was upgraded to ‘Castrol NISMO GT-R’ for 2000 JGTC season, but the car crashed in the first round, being replaced by a new bespoke chassis. NISMO took the IMPUL’s BNR34 late that year to replicate the 1999 JGTC GT500 drivers champion.

>>26259466
A historical racing team named French Speed Connection has bought a JLOC Murcielago and a Taisan Viper (can't remember which year), they're restoring them and plan to race them in the Endurance Racing Legends championship taking place around Europe.
Unfortunately most JGTC/Super GT cars have either been dismantled or stored in some warehouse/yard and collecting dust and/or rust. Sometimes they're put up for sale to free up room, or auctioned off (recent examples include the Jim Gainer 360/430, #666 Bomex Avanzza Vemac, one of the 986 Boxsters that ran in GT300). Another interesting case is the Dijon Racing GT300 Corvette, it ended up being converted to a drift car by Daigo Saito

This is an awful idea on so many levels.

>>26283070
Is the audi 4.2 reliable compared with most german powerplants?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26281331
Why tho

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26284175
A lot of those older VAG engines are pretty solid, the main things to look out for on the 4.2 in particular are the intake manifold flaps (actuators tend to fail over time, making for less low-end torque) and the coil packs (which can be retrofitted for more modern ones with a simple adapter kit).
Chain-driven 4.2 40Vs are a different story (they're a nightmare), 4.2 FSIs still need the occasional major expensive service but they're less likely to slap you with it out of the blue like the chain-driven 40Vs do.

Reminder thats how the clio v6 was born.

An initial idea to drop in the turbocharged three-cylinder 12-valve engine from the Daihatsu Charade GTTi was scorched by problems mating up the electronics, but rather than scaling back his ambitions, Bruen went even wider, He began looking for a car with a wheelbase that would match the 92.3-inch (2345 mm) Twingo’s, and found one in the Ferrari 308 (92.1 inches, 2340 mm), which had a separate chassis, so theoretically could be fairly easily fused with the little Renault.


“The good thing was that the Ferrari came from a different [older] period, so the track was not that wide, whereas the Twingo, for its category was a very wide car,” remembers Breun.

But although he persuaded Renault to donate an unused Twingo shell and came close on more than one occasion to buying an accident-damaged 308 to get the project really rolling, Breun couldn’t quite pull the funds together to make it happen.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dxACf-txT48

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26301422
What do you mean?
The Libero typically only sends power to the rear axle, but the transmission allows locking the front axle to rear axle. When engaged, it's fully locked-- no speed difference allowed. So, you don't want to use it in normal grip circumstances-- you can hurt the transmission by turning on dry pavement with the front axle engaged. Putting a viscous coupling in the middle would allow the axles to move at different speed, so I could just keep the front axle engaged, drive around like normal, and the system will start locking if slippage occurs.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26281079
The more difficult part when i did the change on mine was getting the end links in. Getting the old bar out and new one in was fairly simple.
Si springs can be swapped over as well. 10mm drop, front spring rate is 7% higher (144.2lbs/in vs 126.8lbs/in) while the rears are 32% stiffer (208.8lbs/in vs 158.5lbs/in). Should help with reducing body roll/improving weight transfer, noticed with mine that it feels a bit wallowy when being pushed hard.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26281787
Yeah that was my problem lol. Ended up unbolting the endlinks from the sway bar and bolting them to the control arm first, then the sway bar. I also thought of installing Si springs to keep her OEM+ but I want a modest drop, so I'm installing Eibach Pros next week. So far I've installed a Type R shift assembly, subframe brace, DC strut bar, this sway bar, and soon the springs. I'm out of ideas for what next. Maybe brakes.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26281892
Brakes are a decent choice. DC5R calipers bolt straight on to the knuckle and go well with S2000 rotors, another option would be the Genesis Coupe Brembos paired with Rogue disks. DC5 Creations has a remachined TL Type S caliper that also directly bolts on (OEM ones use an M14 bolt rather than M12), need to use the TL-S rotors for that.

I just need a car in general, and have a max budget of like 2500/3000. >>26302205
Yeah, if you have a 80s or 90s Honda with an pre obd or obd1 ecu like p28, p72, p30, etc it’s probably a good idea to buy a capacitor kit and have them replaced. The main capacitor(the big one) is one of the most common failure points of those, other one being the barometric pressure sensor.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The last of the trve sovl BMWs before they got fat, ugly, and boring to drive in the F-Series Cars alongside the E92 M3 (another classic).

>Reliable, the same N52/6spd drivetrain from a base model 3-Series, no real problems other than coilpacks and oil leaks (valve cover gasket, oil filter houising) at higher miles
>Tons of documentation + aftermarket like every BMW product
>IMPORTANT: Same dimensions as the classic 1990s BMWs. Literally the same length, weight as a E36 M3. Same horsepower too, at 230hp (2012) vs 240hp (1995) just with a open diff. Slightly wider and with a longer wheelbase. Hydraulic Steering so tons of feel vs the older cars.
>IMPORTANT: Overshadowed by the 135i drag/highway pull niggers so they're $4000-10,000 all day long, was BMWs cheapest car in the early 2010s

Give it a rear end upgrade (Decent LSD like a Quaife or OSGiken + higher gears), a good exhaust, and you'll have a ton of fun. And you'll avoid all the bullshit problems the older cars get like the floors trying to tear out or VANOS. Its 230hp/3200lbs in a FR with good steering and suspension, you cannot possibly lose. You can get a extra 20-30hp switching to a 330i/X3 3.0 Intake Manifold and tune

Honestly I'd be pressed between buying one or a 100k mile '13-'15 BRZ/FRS for the same money. The latter is more common, but the BMWs are cheaper and more fun. If you spend more money get a E92 M3 as a project and enjoy the best sports car you can buy (8400rpm ITB'd V8 with 414hp in a 3600lb FR with the best chassis/steering of sports cars from that time period). If you're a Euro all applies to the 130i.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26294891
The ninth gen Pontiac Bonneville.
I was looking for a new car after my '05 Ford Five Hundred got wrecked and I snagged what's probably the cleanest 1994 SE that exists for exactly $2,800. Even had the original order form, window sticker, and other documentation from the dealership/first owner in the manual. Pretty neat.
It's a fun car to drive and has one of the best/most reliable engines ever built (Buick 3800 V6). Motorweek has a really good review on the '93 model year and it's a great car. I've seen a good number of 2000 - 2005 Bonnevilles on the road throughout the years (not even seeing many of those as I used to these days though), but I have only seen another 90s Bonneville once in my entire life (I first started driving in 2004).
And I only saw that one about two weeks ago. Never once before that. I'm not sure how rare of a car it is (probably rare in the sense that it suffered the same fate as 95% of contemporary domestics and that was they were driven, abused beyond all repair, and then scrapped; engines were probably harvested too), but I do believe it's very underappreciated vehicle.
It's just very nice.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26301324
you can't find much information about the k23 engine. It's rarely talked about. I've heard people say it's a k20 block and a k24 head. I don't know if that's bullshit or not. I do know these engines last a long time, and the power band is really impressive. I suspect there are a lot of forged components and some cylinder sleeve lining that is special.

I imagine Honda dumped the k23 because it was a very expensive motor to manufacture, and it gets poor MPG. the Turbo is very expensive.

I bought a high mileage RDX with plans to get me a few years until the auto market calms down. I've dumped some money into it, but the car has 165k on it, and it doesn't rattle at all. I replaced the spark plugs and it idles so smooth I thought the engine died. It's extremely well put together. I did have the radiator break, and the transmission fluid was dumping into the radiator. this is somewhat common. I was extremely lucky to catch it almost right when it happened, and I had no coolant in the tranny.

still, you can get really nice ones 10k, and I don't know what other Honda product is a better used value.

>>26294891
Agreed, the MR2 is a hidden gem, but the Mk1 and Mk2 had a pretty good fan base. The Mk3 is the most underappreciated of them all.

People hated the new styling, the convertible, the bug eyes, and the under powered 1ZZ-FED engine. Mk2 owners wanted a giant 3k lbs twin turbo beast and Mk1 owners probably thought it was too round/hated the modern styling.

IMO this is the best MR2, its lighter than the Mk1, more reliable, the suspencion is excellent, I love the convertible its easy to use and I use it all the time. The styling is not for everyone, but with some side skirts, front lip, and spoiler you can kill the round look and it looks awesome IMO. The engine is a bit of a problem with a meager 140hp, but its agile and quick on the corners, its also reliable as a rock and very fuel efficient. Like 30mpg. You could get 300k on this engine, but theres a precat issue on earlier models.

IMO the best car of the three and I drove all three. Its not practical at all, it doewnt even have a trunk, and it needs some mods, but I dont regret buying it.

posts.sub: How do you decide which car you want?
posts.com:
Obviously we all have limited time and resources, so we can't have every car. I'm someone who like a ton of different cars, and I always have a hard time deciding which car I want.

If you were to have a tie between two cars within you price range, how would you decide?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26304718
easy. List the cars available and I tell you the best one I'm always right.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26304718
>How do you decide which car you want?
My wallet does that for me

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26304718
It depends on many things m8.
Do you want to keep it longterm? Then the part availability is very important. Can you wrench, at least the basics? Is it an easy car to work on? What's the true cost of ownership? And stuff like that.
What do you plan to do with the car? Tracking/Long drives (to work) often/you got a kid?
Did you do research on the forums about reliability and what usually goes bad with the car? Has it been fixed by the previous owner(s)?
Do you have a paint thickness measuremnt tool to see if the car has been repainted? (red flags)
If you want a car that does ''everything'' forget about it. I tried and it isn't possible. The moment you want to track it, it will start going bad. I lost my car because of that (thinking it could do everything, from daily to track car).
If you have a budget of, say 30K, then split it between daily and track/weekend car. Not necessarily 50/50. I did 75/25 in favour of my daily. So that you don't care THAT much if something goes wrong with your weekend car/track tool. If you still can not decide,then toss a Coin. If the result of the coin toss disappoints you, then you know what you truly want.
Think Longterm.

>>26304718

These generic thread faggots never want an actual solution.

1. What's your budget?
2. Can you wrench?
3. Do you want to mod?
4. Do you want to be under the car every weekend?
5. Will you race/drag/drift the car?
6. Can you afford tires, alignments, bushings, brakes, fluid, etc?
7. Do you care about how it looks?
8. Does it need to take you to work every day?
9. Will professional co-workers ever be in the car?
10. Will you use the car for hauling anything other than dragon dildos?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26304718
Make a list of all the cars you're interested in. Randomize the order. Reject the first 1/2.71828 cars on the list. Then go through the list in order (starting after the rejected ones), and buy the first one that is better than all of the already rejected candidates. This will result in an optimal selection about 37% of the time.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26304718
For me it was simple since I wanted an EV. In my price range there were 3 options, a mini cooper, nissan leaf, or chevy bolt/bolt EUV. Bolt mogs the competition with over 100 more miles of range. The leaf also uses a charging standard literally no one else uses anymore. I want an EV because it makes driving with uber more profitable. Fuel is 7 times cheaper than my last car per mile and there is no maintenance outside of rotating tires for the first 150k miles.

I'm currently torn between getting either an E39 M5 or a TVR Griffith 500, and so far I think I'm leaning toward the TVR. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Once I had worked my list of reasonably attainable cars down to a couple I pretty much just sat there until one came up in good condition within my price range, whatever of the two came up first was what I bought
If you cant work it down to a couple, list the things you like about each and go off what car has the most positives
Things like ability to work on it, parts availability, rarity play a small part in deciding but ultimately if its a car you really like, taking a few years to put it together isnt an issue

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26304718
>deciding which car I want
I had various "regular cars": sedan, subcompact, compact, minivan... My dream was a sports car in the radical vein of an Elise. Then I realized a GT would be far better for my usage and that's the category I'm looking at now.
>If you were to have a tie between two cars within you price range, how would you decide?
Holistic approach. Unless we are talking about some hard fuckup, I won't choose either because of slight numerical advantages in anything. Ultimately, I think: "I'm going to spend quite a good amount of money. This car better makes me feel excited and good about it". At that point, maybe looks, sound or some other features could be the deciding factor, talking about 2 very alike cars. Just learn as much as you can about both cars and then follow your heart. Doing lists of pros and cons is pretty useless I've found.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>26303347
Wrong. While yes, a softer compound is generally a more direct route to more grip without the drawbacks (other than longevity and rolling resistance), a wider tire had more *adhesive* forces. Tires do not follow basic friction you learned in high school, there are also adhesive forces (think a piece of tape) that increase with wider tires. The softer the tires get, the greater the adhesive forces to the point some of the softest race tires can pick up a fucking wrench sometimes.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26303380
Most big brakes are an unnecessary LARP. No car should even come close to smoking the most basic of disc brakes on the street, definitely won't during an autocross, shouldn't do it in most HDPE/track day events, etc. The only place big brakes are needed is endurance events with sessions longer than 20 minutes unless there's like a downhill end to a straight into a hairpin and you're stopping from 100+ down to like 20 every lap while gravity is making the job harder. The other issue is cars just being too heavy, Spec Miatas will track around on shitty little midget brakes all day, but a pigfat C8 E Ray is going to need some big brakes at double the weight.

>>26301578
I'd say so. Maintenance records and condition are really what will determine the value. Any big recent job like a matrix/heater core or soft top cylinders is a big plus. Try to get it on a lift and check bushings, engine mounts, so on.
I paid 10k for my 63k mile '00 but I didn't have much in the way of records, and the soft top was boogered. Based on overall condition I decided to go for it.
At the end of the day, anything you'd check on any used car applies here.
>>26301585
All I've done so far is fluids and minor repairs, but no single job was over 100 bucks. The most expensive items i have priced out so far are a new steering box (about 500) and a new set of oem shocks (800). My soft top also needs replacement but I personally don't care as ill likely rarely if ever take the hard top off. If you DIY, for the most part these cars aren't that expensive.

posts.com: Why is it that carburator throttles are mounted vertically on an engine and that throttles for injection systems are mounted horizontally?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Can I install tint (taillight/reflector) in 50-60 degree weather if I heat it up a bit with a heat gun? Should I head the piece I'm applying the tint to prior or just after, and how much heat is enough?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26281198
Both fuel and air flow into the carburetor but fuel, being liquid, works better using gravity to reach the valvetrain and combustion chamber, so the throttle in the carburetor has to be placed horizontally.
Fuel and air intakes are separate in fuel injected engines, so the throttle bodies are able to be installed vertically.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26281712
It doesn't matter, anything in the bottom of the pan that can get lifted will get lifted when you drive, and sent to the filter. Oil changes are frequent enough that leaving some old oil in the pan is irrelevant.
As for the drain valve, you should consider the location of your plug in relation to other hard parts of your vehicle... is it going to get ripped off if you accidentally hit an unmarked speed bump at a higher than normal speed? My car sits low enough and the oil pan is relatively proud so I would be concerned about installing one on mine.

posts.com: Took my car out for a drive and went over the speedometer limit for the first time and started smelling burning, is that normal? Not gonna lie it kind of spooked me and I let off the throttle and drove normal the rest of the way. Nothing seemed damaged under the hood.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26285116
>>26285315
it's a flex plate actually, because it's just a piece of sheet metal that the converter bolts to and holds the ring gear vs a flywheel that is a weighted chunk of steel or aluminum. and no, it won't hurt it to run without the transmission and it won't start at all without the flex plate since, again, it has the ring gear. it might idle a little fast or unstable without all of the weight of the torque converter to stabilize it but it won't harm it.

posts.name: Bepis
posts.com:
>>26278689
>>26278696
There’s a few different types of extractors you can use. The threaded ones are like emergency use and you can grab the 2pk of them at auto parts stores for <$20, but after you thread an overtightened lug into there backwards, it’s pretty much done.

The other type of extractors are good too and can be used more than once. I think they’re easier to use with an impact wrench than with a breaker bar or ratchet, and hammering the extractor on works way better than trying to hammer a 12pt socket on like other people try to recommend. Also if you go this route, don’t buy the cheapest possible Chinese ones off Amazon because they’re not going to bite well or last long. The Irwin ones are solid but they’re overpriced if you buy at the auto parts store. There’s a brand called Rocket Socket that you can find on Amazon and they’re supposed to be really good, not cheap but not overly expensive like some Snap On shit but they will be a livesaver for years to come.

posts.name: Bepis
posts.com:
>>26290961
Try to find a $500 V6 model that’s rusted out or crashed or no title but has a decent engine and trans too, that would be your best bet. The one engine swap I did with a friend was an e36 325i and we dropped the slightly bigger 6cyl with a manual trans into it. And having the donor car was a lifesaver because there’s a bunch of other little bullshit you don’t realize.

Plus if you find a cheap junker 4.0 Ranger for $1000 or less, you can pull your parts, then put a handful of larger good parts for sale like any solid doors or liftgate or wheels, and then scrap the rest of the car for a couple hundred bucks and you can come real close to recovering the money for the junker.

posts.name: Bepis
posts.com:
>>26299552
Could be a million things. Maybe it could be some intermittent electrical thing with some sensor if the car was still running ok. When it gets really cold, everything shrinks, so an older car with already worn wires, the metal and plastic could be shrinking a fraction of a millimeter and losing contact somewhere until stuff heats up. And for lots of those codes, you can trip it and then it takes a few miles of driving without seeing that lean condition again before it goes away on its own, so it obviously happens on those cold stretches.

That’s a generic code that’s going to be hard to diagnose until it pops up with another code or something more obvious happens. Those intermittent issues are a pain in the ass to track down unless you have the scanner with you right when it trips so you can see what the sensor is actually reading and try to troubleshoot it before it goes away.

>>26301158
Are you using a self bleeder kit or vacuum bleeder?

If you're using a self bleeder, make sure there's fluid in the return container, as it will back flow when you stop pumping and have the brake pedal held down.

posts.name: Beppu Von Braun
posts.com:
>>26301158
You’re using a little bleeder container, right?

Even with the little hand vac pump, I prefer bleeding it with somebody else pumping the pedal. Get one of the little bleeder containers and the right size hose for the bleeder, try to get a good fit, make sure the reservoir is topped off in the engine bay.

And the main thing I finally figured out after doing it a couple times, keep the little bleeder container and the hose above the caliper. Tell friend or GF or wife to pump the pedal and hold, open the bleeder, close, tell her to release. With the container above the caliper, the little hose will stay full of fluid and the air goes to the bleeder container, so any flow backwards won’t pull air into the caliper or lines.

posts.com:
I'm new to reading odb2 data. Does this mean my downstream o2 sensor is bad? Just replaced the upstream.

2013 chevy 1500 p015B

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26302332

My understanding is that's what you want to see when both sensors are working properly. The pre-cat sensor oscillates between 0V and 1V as the ECU compensates with fuel trims to maintain as much of a stoic burn ratio as possible. The post-cat sensor holds mostly constant voltage when the cat is doing its job and removing most of the toxic material from the exhaust gas. If your post-cat sensor voltage mirrored the pre-cat sensor, this usually means the cat is below efficiency and needs to be replaced (or deleted along with the P codes in the ECU).

if you're going with a miata you have to be prepared to rust proof it because it will rust. so if you're buying one, get it inspected, get it on a lift and pepper your angus for work, don't buy a rustbucket. don't buy one which has a shitty roof, it's a pain in the ass to do even if you are a mechanic. don't buy the shortnose crank NA (early 1.6s) and if you go for the NB, make sure it has the torsen LSD, no point in having it with an open differential. also make sure you actually build it a little, put some coilovers in there to make it ride actually good. put a supercharger on it to make it actually go fast. supercharging is easier because you can just yank a mini cooper S supercharger, buy an adapter bracket and belt (ready made for the miata) and slap it on there. without an intercooler you're still looking at 175hp of reliable horses with relatively little work all things considered. put an intercooler to get it up to 200hp, it will hold, but it can't hold much more since the transmission and clutch don't want to work with over 200hp

the whole point of a miata really is that you buy a platform and you put mods on it. it won't kill you financially and it will be reliable. the B-series engine it uses is basically a 323 GTX engine with the turbo taken off, but it still has the parts to take the boost, so increasing power is easy because you don't need to open the engine. 200hp with bolt ons in a car that's like 1100kg is the most fun you'll have for the money. also just get a roll hoop. they bolt on relatively easy and you can use it with the soft top and hard top. the soft top will be fine in the winter because the cabin is so small, I've driven mine in -20 and it's no different to my volvo, temperature wise

>>26302412

NA and NB are basically the same car. where they differ is the interior, NB is a nicer place to be in. the engines are also improved in the NB, which means if you're going to build it up, you want the 1.8 BP-Z3 and with that you want the torsen differential. the torsen diff is better than the clutch type LSD because it requires zero maintenance basically (basically just replacing the oil) but due to how torsen differentials work it's very predictable because it will start to lock up when the differential senses when slip is about to occurr. it's mechanical, no electric shit. it's what the big boy audis use and for a good reason. if you find a car without the LSD, it might be hard to get for a reasonable price aftermarket because like the hard top, they are hard to find

NC's are a different car. they are heavier, but more modern. people build these up but they don't have as much build potential. all the nice and affordable parts are for the NA and NB only. I personally would and have gone with the NB miata 1.8 with the torsen differential and it was a great car to drive in the winter because it has ABS so it will stop, but it has no traction control or any other nonsense to limit fun. every corner will be taken sideways when there's snow and ice, for me it was more of a winter car than a summer car. convertibles are kinda overrated if you don't live in california or something, and even if so, going 50 mph or faster just means you'd rather have the top up. and if you have the top up, you want AC. I guess there are some neat canyon roads it could be fun to drive on but few of us have that privilege. also driving it long periods in the sun will cause your skin to burn. you can't wear a hat because it will be blown off by the airflow

just gotta be pessimistic about how great it is during the summer and optimistic at how great it is during winter

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26296107
l6s have perfect primary and secondary balance.
im still unable to fully wrap my head around it, but the primary balance is due to how each piston has an equivalent one going up with it, cancelling out forces that would otherwise result in excessive vibrations. v6s typically need counterweights or countershafts because they are basically two l3 engines side by side.
the secondary balance is perfect because the crank throws (distance from center of crank, to center of the crankpin (where the piston conrod connects to the crank)) are evenly spaced at 120 degree intervals, if you were to look at such a crank head on, the pins would be evenly spaced, kinda like a 3 blade fan.
all this makes for a very smooth running engine with very smooth power delivery.
the problems with an l6 is that it makes for a pretty long engine, so the engine bay has to either be large, or like some euro cars (i think bmw does this with some of theirs), they tuck the rear of the engine under the windscreen wiper cowl so if you need to do any work around there, you need to take off the wipers. this also creates a challenge for today's cars that need to meet safety regs that get tighter and tighter every year; it's quite difficult to make sure that in a head-on crash, the engine block does not go into the passenger cabin.
another is crankshaft torsional vibrations, every time a piston fires the force generated exerts a twisting motion upon the crank. longer cranks will flex, and the straight 6 crank is quite long. This is typically countered with a nice fat harmonic balancer on the end of the crank that isn't connected to the gearbox.
the video below has a great explanation about engine balance
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mTS48jX68YU

I will point out however that this is a question about displacement not "hurr durr v8 > i6" when an i6 with the same displacement as a v8 would be more powerful. These cars are 20 years old, and the Activa system is quite complicated to maintain. All the silentblocks are not necessarily in very good condition. On a specialized forum, some people noticed (especially the red one) that the cars were still rolling a little too much, a sign of a system not in good shape.

And an important detail. The Michelin SX GT tires in 205/60 R15 91W are not available new. And these were really stiff and adapted to the car.
Even the Michelin Pilot Sport 4 is not really sporty. Michelin positioned it between the Primacy 4 and the Pilot Sport 4S.

Anyway, 73km/h, without ESP, with an old car and tires not really adapted to the chassis. It's far from being bad. Especially when you look at some modern cars tests, like the Golf 8.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26302481
>4 pin relay
>remove positive wire from the cig lighter
>power from cig lighter to pin 30 on relay with an inline fuse rated for your expected current draw plus a few amps headroom
>wire pin 87 on the relay to the cig lighter which will be it's new switched power wire
>pin 85 to ground
>pin 86 to a switched power source in the fuse box
The switched power from the fuse box will activate the relay, the relay with then activate the cig lighter by using the battery as it's power source ensuring that you aren't taxing the fusebox wiring with additional load on an existing circuit.
